channel.title: Posts on Practical R
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Practical R

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Introduction Data Visualization Data Science Introduction Are you struggling to learn R so you can create banging data visualizations and produce data science projects that add value? You are not alone. Analyzing data is now common to a lot of professions that may not have any background in programming or computer science. Are you full of excitement for your new R project but finding it difficult to quickly achieve the results you want and need? Coming from a background in other programming languages may be problematic because R does some things a little bit differently. Are you taking a course in R and finding that you can’t keep up with the class and need some background? Or are you just interested in learning more about R and what R can do? I would like to help you do more with R. I want to inspire you to create your own data visualizations, master data science, or develop your own data stories.

item.title: Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.

item.title: Rich Content
item.description: Hugo ships with several Built-in Shortcodes for rich content, along with a Privacy Config and a set of Simple Shortcodes that enable static and no-JS versions of various social media embeds.

item.title: Placeholder Text
item.description:
Mole et vultus populifer quaque primoque non

Lorem est tota propiore conpellat pectoribus de pectora summo.

item.title: Math Typesetting
item.description: Mathematical notation in a Hugo project can be enabled by using third party JavaScript libraries.

item.title: Emoji Support
item.description: Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways.
